72734650.review:
An ultimate chill game to keep your mind at ease, with an added bonus if you are in for countless exploration and adventuring. This game is at the best of both worlds. 

[u]Pro(s)[/u]
[list]
[*] [b]Lovely Pixel Art:[/b] Overall graphics are simple and awesome

[*] [b]Calming and Peaceful:[/b] Audio track induces really chill vibes, no stresss

[*] [b]Paced and Relaxed Storyline:[/b] Straight to the point storyline - The game revolves around you being the hero after defeating the dark wizard and rebuilding your very own town. As day passes in the game, there will be new variants such as new townfolks, town objects and items, depending on what you do in an in-game day. There is no rush into anything and you can take your time to figure things out (playing at a pace you like can essentially prevent grinding xD)

[*] [b]Simple Movement & Customisation:[/b] The building mode in the game is reliant on mostly 4 arrow clicks (up,down,left & right)/WASD and spacebar for placement or removal of different town objects, making it relatively easy for players

[*] [b]Exploration:[/b] Countless adventuring to unlock various maps, items, structures and meet travelers

[*] [b]Character Upgrades:[/b] You get to upgrade your skills through building, cooking, farming, mining, woodcutting etc.

[*] [b]Interactive:[/b] Get to know the background of different townfolks through day-to-day interaction, although i must admit the dialogue with them gets repetitive after some time.

[*] [b]Thrill:[/b] Hunt for rare and exotic items & pets and earn $$(Dewdrops) 

[*] [b]Fun:[/b] One thing i really like about the game is that there is a mini tarott card game in it, which really test your brain to win your opponent :D You will get to meet weak to strong opponents and you have to choose your deck cards wisely, one really entertaining element in the game to past time!

[*] [b]Events:[/b] On special days, you get to encounter something different!
[/list]

[u]Con(s)[/u]
[list]
[*] [b]Relatively Repetitive:[/b] Some days you might find yourself doing the same thing over again and might get slightly out of mood. I recommend playing in moderation mostly, but if you have tons of tasks on your bucket list in the game to complete, then preferably you can invest more time into playing and completing them :]

[*] [b]Limited Daily Energy:[/b] A thing to note about the game is that each day you have a limited amount of energy to do what you want (woodcutting, mining etc) and what you want to do might be put on a hold until the next in-game day when your energy runs out. With that said, you may have to plan what to do day to day to optimize your energy and frustration can come along at times.

[*] [b]Repetitive Dialogue with Townfolks:[/b] Do not expect the townfolks to speak something different each time you talk to them. After some point of time, you are bound to notice them saying the same things over, but that cant be help since they are NPCs in general and have limitations as to their dialogue.

[*] [b]Definite Minimal Grinding:[/b] Do expect minimal grinding when you buy the game. No doubt that there will be a point of time where you will reach an endless loop of grind to unlock the endgame. But of course, you can chill and take things slow ^^
 

[/list]
 
To sum it up,  getting to chill is one of the highlighting elements in this game. I have no regrets spending money on it as i come back time to time whenever i feel like chilling. In addition, to all the possible shortcomings of the game, active content are being updated from time to time in attempts to resolve or improve them ^^

73803542.review:
You gather materials.
You process those materials into planks and bricks
You build houses.
You gather more materials.
You build fancy stuff and necessities for those houses.
You get chummy with people and let them settle in yout town.
You build houses and open job opportunities for these people.

And eventually all these relationships, houses, and jobs you build will unlock more places and bueprints that'll help you in making Littlewood or [i]*insert town name here*[/i] to be the prettiest, most prosperous town in a world that finally got its peace after you defeated the evil Dark Wizard.

Lastly, you're also given terraforming right from the start, pretty much given full freedom to shape your town into your liking. It is a bit limited by resources at the beginning, but it really only limits you from making some crazy levelled town design which is completely possible the deeper you go into the game.

It's the kind of game that's hard to find any fault in as long as you don't expect to play a deep base building RPG or something... It's a fun, casual game akin to Stardew Valley and Animal Crossing, with more similarities to the latter.

If there's anything that's lacking from this game, is that it isn't as micromanage-y as Stardew and lacks the social feels kind of brand from Animal Crossing. But it does find its own comfortable place in-between those two games. 
...Oh, and the fact that you can only build stairs on a specific direction(vertically from bottom to top, you can't build stairs side-ways). Sounds mundane but it does limit player's creativity by a bit.

But regardless of that, the "Overwhelmingly Positive" is absolutely well deserved. Devs put their love and hard work into this game and it just shows.

73853078.review:
tl;dr: If you like mobile games with a daily stamina meter, RNG, and taking a long time to marry someone who only says 1 unique comment to you per day, smash that buy button.

You might be thinking, “gosh that wasn’t a very favorable review, why is this asshole recommending this game?”
Because Littlewood, despite its obvious trap, is a very enjoyable Skinner box/dopamine button. Like Forager before it, Littlewood lures you in with promises of bright, indie visuals and cheap decorating fun before it chains your ankles and wrists to the bedposts for ten hours of your life. You might be wondering where does the time go as you get absorbed into the shallow gameplay and, shocker, it’s that same gameplay loop of just one more upgrade, one more fish, one more in-game day to witness the fruits of your labor!

The npcs have no depth gameplay wise, everyday you can chat, compliment, and hang out with them while they throw money at you like this is a OnlyFans ACNH date. And yet I keep crawling back like the morosexual I am because somewhere along the way I grew to care about these quiet weirdos that chase me around while I gather more material for crafting bricks.

All in all: Littlewood is my personal hell that I can’t climb out of until I marry the Dark Wizard and we adopt a dog.

73890741.review:
I feel like I'm playing an F2P game with time-gated mechanics and an insane amount of grinding.

I want to like it, but I spend so much time just grinding. And it wouldn't be that bad if the game would let me grind, but it doesn't. Every 5 minutes I have to return to home and sleep and come out and go back to the grinding spot to grind again.

This is ignoring doing anything else in town, of which every time you sleep you need to talk to every town person and harvest your stuff. So every time you sleep, you gotta talk to people, put stuff in the market, go to cafe to get your one buff, then go to the forest to chop wood. Chop down maybe 6 - 7 trees. Run out of energy. 

Go to sleep. Next day, repeat the boring daily stuff.

Convert planks to 24 wood. Upgrade 2 things 1/3 of the way with 24 wood.

Go to sleep.

It's pretty crazy how little energy you have.

You're only allowed a max of 6 fruit trees. Max of 6 vegetables. I haven't had any luck in the RNG town upgrades so I'm still stuck at 6 fruit trees after 5 hours of play and about 12 vegetables.

Dude, just let me plant fruit trees.

I've also given up on trying to upgrade any of the villagers' requests as everything is RNG on what you can get.

Lastly, while building the town is quite fun, it's an extreme chore to move things around or rearrange the layout once you've got a sizeable thing going. The controls are really clunky to move stuff around or swap items. I built my roads too small and need to widen them, but just thinking about redoing the town layout makes me want to uninstall. Why can't we just use the mouse?

It's hard for me to recommend this, when something like Stardew Valley or Rune Factory does this significantly better.

Recommendations to dev:
1. Please make it less RNG, especially for really basic upgrades like crop and tree amounts.
2. Please do something about the grind.
3. Please give mouse controls for the town, or a way to mass delete everything.

73796192.review:
I've been with Littlewood for a long time now, as one of the original Kickstarter backers I've gotten to play from it's early conception to now 1.0.

I still remember how excited and hopeful I was when I played the original free demo and even now 150+ hours later I still find Littlewood to be extremely relaxing to play.

There is rarely ever any time crunch to push you, outside of a few holiday events. Your 'time' is the actions you take. So you are free to get up and answer the door, or plan out your moves in detail without worrying you are missing anything.

Building your town is a day one feature, you don't have to unlock the chance to terraform so you can start right away.

The characters are all cute and interesting, letting you pick whoever it is (save grandpa Dudley) that you want to romance. I've enjoyed all the little special moments I've gotten to seen between the other characters and hope this is something Sean continues to expand on post 1.0.

I love this game, and whole heartedly can recommend it to anyone looking for a relaxed, at your own pace building/life sim game.

74000574.review:
It's very charming, relaxing and addicting to play, but after you've been at it for a while you really start to notice that there's a mountain of tedious grind and not much actual gameplay or story.  Initially the pacing is fine, but once you get into upgrading your buildings the material costs skyrocket.  There's no combat and the fishing and farming mechanics are extremely simple and limited; the game actually hardcaps how many things you can plant, and it's a very low number even after you upgrade the limit later.  There is a semi-interesting card game you can play that's alright at least.  Character events are very barebanes, you get 3 '''dates''' per characters and they're all virtually the same beyond a few lines of dialogue.  There's a couple dozen general events between the characters that are more interesting, but just when it looks like you might see some actual character development they end.

So that leaves the town building, which is the main selling point from the game description.  And again, at first it's neat.  You have almost full control over everything, and the the UI is well designed and easy to use.  Great, right?  Except you run out of buildings that have any actual function very quickly, leaving just decorations.  Town decorations for some same strange reason cost a small fortune and usually need rare drop material to boot.  That's assuming you even get the plans you want, which are 100% RNG on whether the shops sell them.  It very quickly kills any incentive to play with the town layout, and you just grind away hitting rocks and trees hoping the next building upgrades will open up something more interesting.  They don't.

It's not all bad, it was enjoyable enough to hold my interest for a while.  It's kind of funny since many aspects of the game try to avoid wasting your time; there's always a 'return to home' button one click away, you don't have to sit there watering your plants every day, you can design the town layout to be as convenient as possible for yourself, etc.  But there's just too much empty grind past the early game.  A patch or mod that drastically cut down on the material costs of everything would instantly reverse my rating.

This game really just isn't my taste. It's enjoyable enough at the beginning. Once the game finishes its tutorials, you're left to your own devices for the most part. This is without a doubt the most relaxing game I have ever played. The best way I could describe it is a more chill version of Stardew Valley or Animal Crossing with the flavor of an RPG.

The fact that the day progresses as you take actions (as opposed to a timer set to the IRL passage of time) means you can run either around and plan out exactly what you want to spend your actions doing for that game day if you want to micro-manage everything still (I get it, I'm like that sometimes) but even if you don't have time to do everything you want it's ok. Villagers don't seem to mind if they have to sleep outside for a couple nights (it's not my fault you need fancy planks for your house!) and while I've only played for a couple hours but it seems to me the only really penalty for advancing time is purchase availability rotating, meaning you might have to wait for something you wanted but couldn't afford to come back around.

73730694.review:
Have spent over 80 hours in game so far and there is definitely a lot of content (still more coming at the time of comment). I think this game can be described in a word as uniquely "customizable," or simply "relaxing." You can change the layout of your town (with some restrictions, but fewer than other games), change appearance, change the land in your town, forge friendships, recieve and exchange gifts, hang out with others, buy and raise pets, mine, farm, collect flowers, buy community upgrades, sell for profit, fish, collect artifacts, and much more.

I also love the variety of the characters in this game, each with their own personalities and different interactions on holidays in game. Lots of different locations, marriage included and lots of other small quality detailing make this game really relaxing and easy to play. This game does have some grinding, but isn't timed, so it's a great experience if you just want to create your own world without the hassle of pressure that a lot of other farming games or simulators give you. Instead, this is a indie game designed to give an experience of building your world from scratch and getting close to those within it. I highly recommend it as one of my favorite farming games. I've always wanted a town from scratch and this game gave me exactly that, complete with a fun community of NPC interactions.

I think a game like this would be similar to a "Post Game" in Dark Cloud series. 

The world has been saved! And now you return "home" to rebuild it. Your "Build Mode" is unlocked the moment you start a new game, giving you the power to place houses where you want, make lakes and/or mountains. It is all up to you! As you build your town and explore the world, new people will want to move in -- and you build a house for them.
There's bug catching, hosting your own marketplace, fishing, cooking, mining, wood refining, ore refining

73921523.review:
A slightly reserved recommendation. Short version: a great way to spend a couple dozen hours relaxing, but missing the parts of its key influences that might make you remember it for years.

The reason I decided to write a review at all was the NPCs. Stardew Valley played familiar gameplay favorites, not too revolutionary there... but it had sympathetic, interesting characters that stayed with you. I did not find that here.

NPCs have zero to one trait: Dalton is excited and has food on his face, Busby is mean, Lilith is angry. But wait, how can an NPC have zero traits? Oh, I don't count the trait that all NPCs share: obsession over you, the protagonist. The game passes the Bechdel test with the Don Rickles defense, saying, "I insult characters of all genders equally!" 

And it pans out in a completely predictable way: Ash, the hapless dude-in-distress who says he "can't keep waiting for a hero to rescue [him]" and then moves in with an explicit desire to date is charming for being a twist on the tropes. Willow, the girl-next-door who has a Secret Past (loving you) and not-secret present (loving you) is eye-rollingly uninteresting.

Like Stardew Valley and Harvest Moon, when you reach friendship thresholds, you get cutscenes that, in those games, shed some light on the characters' personalities and relationships between each other. Special Moments in Littlewood seem to somehow not do that. Instead they illustrate some... sequence of events or conversation, that touches on the zero-to-one trait of one of the characters involved, but don't elaborate on them at all. 

To sum it all up, the Special Moment between Busby, the snooty town chef, and Laura, the library nerd: Laura asks Busby to teach her how to cook. Busby says "NO!!! Hero and I are the best cooks!!" Laura asks if she can be the third-best cook. Busby says "NO!!! Cooking is something special between Hero and I. You wouldn't understand!" The End.

What? So what we've learned from this is:
* Laura is a nerd and wants to learn things (sure, I knew that)
* Busby is an a**hole (sure, I knew that)
* Busby is obsessed with me (he was a Littlewood NPC)

Maybe there's some progression here, with Busby grudgingly taking Laura under his wing (ha). But there's only 32 Special Moments, so if we're starting here, I can't imagine we're going to get into why Laura wants to learn cooking, or why Busby doesn't want to teach her. It seems like it's just because she's a nerd, and he's a jerk.

Is it worse than average video game writing? No, probably not. But it checks so many other boxes for me so well that this whiff feels more disappointing. I'll still play it for another 10 hours or so, and I'd still say it's worth playing.

PROS

* Dark Cloud-style town-building: I love puzzle-guided town-building way more than I think I love free-form town-building
* cool time mechanic: no need to fret about having enough time to get home at the end of the day: the clock and your stamina meter are the same thing... which is also why you can just teleport home when you're done chopping 20 trees.
* shorter days than SV or HM: since the days are self-paced, they can fly by once you decide what to do with them.
* very cute SNES graphics: you see em.

CONS

* NPC writing
* samey upgrades:
* it seems like skill increases have no effect outside of gating new trees and ores you can interact with. 
* only 3 out of 9 levels of building upgrades do anything thematic at all: 6 give you some rare secondary currency. The functional upgrades seem to always be a simple linear upgrade, with no choices or much flavor.

73761912.review:
A deceptively simple alternative to Harvest Moon, Animal Crossing, etc., with a focus on townbuilding. Love it! 

- 100% the best graphics of any game like it. They are very polished and consistent. I cannot stress this enough, the graphics tend to be what pushes me away from similar games. God bless Stardew Valley but the creator is definitely not a pixel artist. The GBA Pokemon-like style of Littlewood is pulled off well with a modern feel. Best part of the game, hands down.

- The gameplay is smooth and focuses on convenience over "realism" in some areas. You can instantly teleport home from anywhere. You can enter "build mode" which lets you play God to rearrange everything about your village. There's a lot of creative freedom. You also don't need a mouse to play which is an underrated benefit. My only gripe is, while there are a lot of keybind alternatives, you cannot change the keybinds to whatever you wish. If you are used to "E" being the "activate" button then this game with totally screw with you for the first few hours. But you get used to it.

- The game has depth! There are a billion things to unlock from items, villagers, decorations, places to explore, buildings and their multiple of upgrades -- it goes on and on. PLENTY of ways to make money, but it doesn't feel overwhelming. Nothing feels like it is too out of reach. There's a lot of thought into the "late-game" which I appreciate. There's even a Hearthstone-like card game you can play with the villagers which is a fairly difficult, rewarding, and enjoyable challenge. 

- Time is based on number of actions rather than a race against the clock. This is how it should be done! There is no stress. The days might go by a little too quickly but there are late game unlocks which help reduce that feeling.

- The villagers are adorable, you can flirt and go on multiple dates with (almost) all of them. I also love that you can have one of them tag along with you at your leisure. They all have their personalities and requests which you can fulfill to unlock content. It takes quite a bit of time to unlock every villager so you never feel idle in that regard.

I'm very satisfied with Littlewood, I see myself sinking in a hundred hours or more. There is nothing on the market like it right now. I really hope it gets mod support one day, because that would make a 10/10 game into an 11/10.

There are only two things I hate about this game: the trading card mini-game (tarot monster) because I really hate TCGs and flower breeding, which gets really frustrating when flower RNG gets very very stubborn at end-game. Tarot monster card game can be ignored as far as I've seen which I happily did all you lose is a statue but you need the "right flowers" to unlock a location on the map. I have literally everything else other than tarot monster BS maxed out yet still can't get to the 1 area because I can't get the right flowers to grow. I've pretty much picked up and replanted and regrew flowers to cover half the town four times over to no avail. Seriously... f**k flowers... 

Jokes aside I wish there was some sort of a greenhouse like place where you could easily breed the damned things, have more control over it.

You can only change colors of your own house more in the end-gameish bits. It's not a huge deal though, there are loads of decorations you can find and/or buy. When you do all your chores and talk to everyone on a daily basis, keep good relations, decorate townsfolks' houses you get useful gifts which makes things easier and more convenient. Some of the skill rewards when you cap them like gathering cooking crafting etc are very useful some of them might seem a bit mehh. Overall though reaching the useful stuff is not exhausting, progression didn't feel tedious to me.

All in all I love this little game.

72245661.review:
[b]Littlewood is an incredibly relaxing game that offers a slightly different take on the usual games in this genre. [/b]

20 hours in over three days and I am loving this game. It has become a small addiction of mine.
In Littlewood you play a character who, now the big bad evil has been defeated, must rebuild their town. You achieve this by meeting new people who want to move in, building them houses, building and upgrading various different shops and crafting stations and participating in festivals. It follows the basic steps of other similar games but feels much more relaxing and simpler. There is a museum for collecting, a tavern for cooking, a forest for gathering, fishing and woodcutting, and a mine for mining and bug catching as well as few other locations to explore. 

There are 15ish villagers who you can eventually have move into your town, and a few others characters you can meet and talk to and festivals that happen in your town on set days that you can participate in. You have skills such as farming, gathering, woodcutting and more which can be levelled up by performing the corresponding actions and rewards will unlock as you progress. Currently there seems to be no advantage to higher levels skills aside from unlocking some late game content such as the bug tree and the fishing boat but this may change as the game is developed. Blueprints for furniture and decorations are found and bought as you play and there is PLENTY of customization for your house and the other villager houses which is a huge plus as you can control what your townspeople’s houses look like. HOWEVER, there is a mechanic in the game where villagers want specific items in their house, so you are kind of railroaded into them looking a certain way if you’re going for 100% completion.

One of my favourite features is the level of control you have over your village. You can move everything so you can make your village look exactly how you want. This includes adding and removing water, lowering, or raising terrain, moving houses, buildings, trees, crops and decorations as you see fit. I personally went for the most efficient layout I could thing of but if you’re someone who likes things looking perfect, you have that ability. Once again villagers prefer to be close or far from certain other buildings so if you are going for 100% completion you may not be able to have your village exactly as you want it. 

There isn’t as much pressure in Littlewood as there are in games such as Harvest Moon and Stardew Valley because there isn’t a clock that ticks down constantly. Instead the time of day is tied to your stamina and each action advances the day. This means you can explore and talk to people freely without pressure to rush around whilst still ensuring days are a set length of time. But there are grindy elements of the game, but I feel this is a common theme in games life this. You will be going on collect quests, farming a lot of resources and upgrading buildings multiple times. Some people might take issue with this, but it is actually one of the things I enjoy most about this genre; I always have a clear goal to work towards. Littlewood feels like a simplified version of Harvest Moon with some MAJOR improvements to certain elements of the gameplay. You do not need to replant crops constantly; all crops grow back. You can save at any point, not just before bed. Inventory space is unlimited so you can forage to your hearts content. For me, these are all things I had wanted in similar games but never found. 

My only big issue I have had with the game so far is the fact that things aren’t very clear to you which can cause mistakes. I fed a ghost fruit I had to an animal quite early. Since then I haven’t found another single Ghost Fruit so I cannot plant more to get more. I am unsure if I am missing something but as I said, it’s not overtly clear you can only obtain certain items once.

I’ve been playing for 20 hours and there was a small lull around the 15 hour mark where the grind was heavy as I worked towards ‘end-game’ activities but once I passed it I found my enjoyment of the game peak again. I can see myself revisiting the game with each new patch and it’s one of the few games I am excited to see in it’s final stage. I think it has enough content to justify it’s price but if you’re looking for something as fleshed out as Stardew you might want to wait it out a little longer.

[b] Pros: [/b]
Relaxing low-pressure game. 
Easy to understand, easy to play, easy to master. 
Full village customization.

[b] Cons: [/b]
Achievements are a grindfest and nothing more. Hopefully this will change as the game is developed because I’m not sure I want to grind 6000 of each skill to 100% the game. 
Could do with a few QOL improvements.


[b]THIS IS AN EARLY ACCESS REVIEW OF A GAME THAT IS NOT YET COMPLETE. THINGS MAY CHANGE, THEY MAY NOT. I AM REVIEWING THE GAME IN IT’S CURRENT STATE: v0.97.[/b]

71466286.review:
This game is distilled chill. If you have a busy brain, and just want something to relax with, this game will give you that. It is as if someone crossed Stardew Valley and Animal Crossing, taking relationships with a village of folks you may want to fall in love with from one and the need to collect everything [at your own pace] from the other. 

That said, the relationships are not nearly as in depth or as unique from character to character as Stardew is. Maybe it's just the level of development right now, but most of the relationships feel pretty samey outside of one or two characters. There's still some cute stuff, but don't expect your presence in anyone's life to change who they are or ferry them through their own character arc. This game isn't a dating sim, it's an extremely chill RPG with some dating mechanics.

69585066.review:
**Review based on the Linux version**

Littlewood is heavily inspired by Animal Crossing, with a few elements from Harvest Moon series (or Stardew Valley, that improved the whole thing). This is not a "Stardew Valley lite" as some may think, this is a town builder with social elements and resource gathering and management. The building part include home decoration just like in Animal Crossing, you have to collect blueprints to build furniture and town elements.

Things are a bit more interesting than the classic Animal Crossing because there are some mini-games and some mechanics to suggest you stuff to do and give you a bonus. Inside the game there is a Magic: The Gathering-like card  game, with cards you collect during gameplay,

The graphics are simple but very cute, the level of detail is lower than some other pixel art games but in my opinion it makes the game cozier. This is a great game to relax and play with your family, language is toned down.

By the time I wrote this review, the game was near release status, very playable with plenty of things to do. If the developer keeps working on this later, it will be fun to see new stuff being added while you play.

I absolutely loved this game. The community around it is great and the developer is accessible and is listening to us and delivering what we ask. I hope I can help to make this game more popular as it deserves to be an indie classic as it clearly was made with love.

72271257.review: I am always in the mood for farming sims and after "accidentally" spending all day with this one, it's a definite new favorite. A major draw is definitely the town-building tools, which you get access to basically immediately. I think the most interesting feature, and what sets it apart from other games of its type for me, is that instead of time passing steadily, your energy bar determines what time of day it is; as your character gets more tired, it gets later. The disadvantage of this is that there's no way to refill the energy bar, but what it results in is avoiding the frantic rush to get tasks done that many other farming games eventually become. Strategically spending your energy is much less stressful than racing against the clock, which perfectly suits Littlewood's easygoing mood. If you like Harvest Moon, Stardew Valley and their many sibilings, add this one to your collection. I'm really looking forward to spending lots more time with it!

70533907.review:
[i] Essa é a minha primeira experiência com jogos com uma pegada mais chill, então a análise vai ser muito baseada na experiência que eu tive com o jogo, cada um pode ter uma diferente, portanto talvez nem todos concordem. 
Eu não irei dar nenhum spoiler, e tentarei não falar sobre muita coisa do jogo para que você consiga descobrir sozinho jogando. Lembrando que está em acesso antecipado por enquanto, mas no final de julho irá ser lançada a versão 1.0, quando chegar eu atualizarei a análise e mudarei algo se eu achar necessário! [/i]

[h1] Littlewood [/h1] é um game que consegue fazer muito bem o que deseja: ser [i] um jogo casual, super relaxante e prazeroso/gostoso de se jogar. [/i]

Eu amei muito jogar e acredito que todos que jogaram se sentiram super bem jogando, pois o jogo trás uma vibe muito boa e transmite ela muito bem para o jogador. Se você está a procura de um bom jogo para relaxar e jogar tranquilo: essa é a escolha perfeita!
[i] (e para você curte um lo-fi, só ligar um de fundo que a gameplay se torna 200% mais gostosa de se jogar). [/i]

[b] Enredo [/b]

O jogo se passa em um planeta chamado Solemn, um mundo onde a magia é algo relativamente normal e se tornou um lugar tranquilo e sem ameaças preocupantes, pois após “The hero of Solemn” (você) ter derrotado o grande Bruxo das Trevas (“Dark Wizard”) trouxe a paz a Solemn.
No início do jogo você percebe que não tem memória alguma do que houve ou do seu passado, mas percebe que foi alguém muito relevante, o seu objetivo é reconstruir sua cidade (Littlewood), conhecer pessoas, coletar recursos e explorar Solemn.
É um enredo bem simples, mas que eu adorei pois ajuda em toda vibe do jogo e me ajudou a emergir nesse universo de Littlewood, o passado do personagem e de Solemn é meio misterioso, mas acredito que vá ter mais resquícios sobre ele nas versões finais ou em outras atualizações, mas no final das contas isso é o de menos - seria apenas um fanservice (positivo) para os jogadores visto que o jogo procura focar em outras coisas.

[b] Gráficos e trilha sonora [/b]

Littlewood possui gráficos bem fofos e agradavelmente bonitos, por serem pixelados não é uma obra de arte super detalhada, mas são bonitos e casam muito bem com o objetivo do jogo. 
Eu pessoalmente achei que os gráficos lembram até que bastante Pokémon (os mais antigos, como o Heart Gold e outros), mas é apenas uma observação minha mesmo.

A trilha sonora do jogo é bem simples também, então não tenho nada a enaltecer, mas nada a criticar, combinam bastante com o jogo e o momento da gameplay, fazendo uma boa atmosfera de fundo. 
[i] (só que eu recomendo fortemente jogar com um lo-fi de fundo caso gostem desse gênero de música, ou que deem uma chance caso não conheçam) [/i]


[b] Gameplay [/b]

O jogo tem o objetivo de ser um life sim RPG de exploração bem relaxante, e cumpre muito bem isso - comandos simples, não existe combate algum no game (exceto pelos “Tarrot Master”: um jogo de cartas simples que pode lembrar um pouco HeartStone e Pokémon TCG, mas simplificado e com seu estilo único), ele te proporciona uma liberdade muito alta para você construir sua cidade: o que torna o jogo super divertido (você pode modificar todo o terreno dela, quase zero limitações, pode até criar ou modificar montanhas, rios, etc.) e dá uma satisfação maior em construir sua cidade, pois foi você que a fez completamente, desde a posição das casas até rios e relevos!

Outro ponto positivo é que você nunca se sente sozinho, porque você vai ir conhecendo e interagindo com NPCs, e eu até esquecia que são apenas NPCs de tão bem feitos que são, são bem divertidos e humanos, cada um com o seu jeito e gostos, claro que depois acaba se tornando um pouco repetitivo depois de interagir muitas e muitas vezes com eles, mas compreendo o lado do desenvolvedor. Além do mais, você pode ir pegando intimidade com eles, e chega até acontecer um romance de leve entre eles e o protagonista (mas nada que chegue a nível de um relacionamento sério que mostre detalhes, apenas um romance que rolou sem tanto compromisso e pronto, mas ao menos é permitido você passar um rodo em geral), e o melhor de tudo: pode sim ser um casal LGBT. E mais uma coisa! Existem algumas cutscenes (chamadas de “Special Moments”) no jogo que você vai desbloqueando, e todas elas são ótimas, e algumas super engraçadas, gostei e me diverti muito com toda e qualquer interação que tive com os NPCs, sejam em cutscene ou não.

Por ser um rpg, existem algumas mecânicas de progressão no jogo e desbloqueio de coisa no jogo, que não desejo entrar em muito detalhe, mas me agradou bastante e o tanto de coisas que existe para se fazer no jogo também me deixou satisfeito (ainda nem fiz 100% do jogo, e haverá ainda mais coisa após a versão completa do game).

———————————


O jogo ainda não tem tradução, mas quem sabe futuramente né! Seria incrível e muito mais imersivo, nós (e todos os idiomas que tiverem tradução) ficaríamos super felizes!!!

Deem uma olhada na discussão que criei sobre o assunto e apoiem se desejarem:
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/894940/discussions/0/2443713646282574957/] "Game translation into portuguese"[/url] 

[i] Agradeço desde já a atenção! [/i]
———————————


Eu pessoalmente amei muito o jogo (candidato a ser top 3 na minha lista de jogos favoritos) e acredito que com o tempo irá me render umas 100 a 200 horas de jogo, e na versão completa do jogo poderá render até mais.

[i] Obs: Eu sou do tipo de jogadora que faz 100% do jogo, portanto não sei quanto tempo de jogo pode render a cada um! [/i]

69184937.review:
Littlewood é um RPG de simulação estilo Stardew Valley e Harvest Moon. O jogo foca muito em ser um RPG relaxante, sem combate. É aquele tipo de jogo fofinho que a gente joga pra passar o tempo.
Muita gente diz que o jogo é uma cópia de Stardew, mas isso é obviamente uma desinformação de alguém que não jogou. O principal diferencial do jogo que até faz eu preferir ele do que outros jogos do mesmo gênero, é a total liberdade que é te dada, você pode construir sua cidade do jeito que bem entender, sem limitações. Isso é realmente um ponto muito forte no game que me agrada muito. 
Os NPCs também são MUITO bem feitos, cada um com sua própria história, personalidade, manias e objetivos.
Agora sobre a questão da progressão do jogo, ela também é bem decente, você consegue evoluir e investir em todas as estruturas do jogo (com excessão das casas), e isso faz com que você libere mais features desse local e faz com que ele melhore de maneira geral.
Sobre a lore do jogo, ela é interessante também, basicamente você é o herói que salvou o mundo, e agora deve construir uma cidade para reerguer a civilização novamente.
Eu encaro o jogo como uma sequência espiritual do game Magicite, que foi criado pelo mesmo desenvolvedor e fez um certo sucesso no Brasil na época que foi lançado. Fica muito evidente isso no game por várias referências que são feitas e que indicam à isso, além de a história ser bem semelhante.
Enfim, Littlewood é um jogo que eu recomendaria para qualquer um que quer uma experiência tranquila/relaxante e gosta de RPG ou Life Sim do estilo que eu citei mais acima.
